chapter.title: Installing Web Policy Agents in Apache HTTP Server
chapter.para: This chapter covers prerequisites and installation procedures for Web Policy Agents ${agentsDocTargetVersion} into Apache HTTP Servers 2.2.x and 2.4.x.

section.title: Before You Install
section.para: This section describes the prerequisite steps you should take before installing the web policy agents into Apache HTTP servers.

listitem.para: Avoid installing the web server and the web policy agent as root. Instead, create a web server user and install as that user.

If you cannot avoid installing the web server and web policy agent as root, then you must give all users read and write permissions to the logs and logs/debug directories under the agent instance directory (/web_agents/type/Agent_nnn/logs/). Otherwise, the web policy agent fails with an error when attempting to rotate log files.

tip.para: The installer can automatically set permissions on folders that require write access, by reading the Apache config file to determine the correct group and user to grant privileges to. Answer yes when prompted:
tip.screen: Change ownership of created directories using User and Group settings in httpd.conf [ q or 'ctrl+c' to exit ] (yes/no): [no]: yes

listitem.para: The SELinux OS feature can prevent the agents from being able to write to audit and debug logs. See .
Ensure OpenAM is installed and running, so that you can contact OpenAM from the system running the policy agent.
Create a profile for your policy agent as described in .

Create at least one policy in OpenAM to protect resources with the agent, as described in the section on Configuring Policies. Consider creating a simple policy, such as a policy that allows only authenticated users to access your resources. This allows you to test your policy agent after installation.
If the OpenAM server uses SSL, you must install OpenSSL on the agent machine.
On UNIX systems, ensure the OpenSSL libraries libcrypto.so and libssl.so are available in the path specified by either the LD_LIBRARY_PATH or LD_LIBRARY_PATH_64 environment variables.
On Windows systems, ensure the OpenSSL libraries libeay32.dll and ssleay32.dll are available in the lib folder of your agent installation, for example c:\path\to\web_agents\iis_agent\lib\.

note.para: On Windows 2012 Systems, you need to place a copy of the OpenSSL library DLLs into %SystemRoot%/System32/.

listitem.para: Install Apache HTTP Server before you install the policy agent. You must stop the server during installation.
Unzip the file in the directory where you plan to install the web policy agent. The agent stores its configuration and logs under this directory.
When you unzip the policy agent .zip download, you find the following directories:

section.title: Installing Apache Web Policy Agents
section.para: Complete the following procedures to install Web Policy Agents ${agentsDocTargetVersion} into Apache HTTP Servers.

tip.para: Check that you have completed any prerequisite steps before proceeding. See .

section.para: There are two web policy agents packages available for Apache installs:

listitem.para: Available in 32-bit and 64-bit. By default, extracts to a folder named ./web_agents/apache22_agent/.
Available in 32-bit and 64-bit. By default, extracts to a folder named ./web_agents/apache24_agent/.

tip.para: The following procedures show how to install into Apache 2.4. If installing into Apache 2.2, alter the path names accordingly.

procedure.title: To Install the Web Policy Agent into Apache

step.para: Shut down the Apache server where you plan to install the agent.
Make sure OpenAM is running.
Run agentadmin --i to install the agent.
UNIX example:
step.screen: $ cd /web_agents/apache24_agent/bin/ $ ./agentadmin --i --acceptLicence

step.para: Windows example:
step.screen: C:\> cd web_agents\apache24_agent\bin C:\path\to\web_agents\apache24_agent\bin> agentadmin.exe --i --acceptLicence

step.para: When prompted for information, enter the inputs appropriate for your deployment.

tip.para: You can cancel web policy agent installation at anytime by pressing CTRL+C

step.para: Enter the full path to the Apache HTTP Server configuration file. The installer modifies this file to include the web policy agent configuration and module.
step.screen: Enter the complete path to the httpd.conf file which is used by Apache HTTPD Server to store its configuration. [ q or 'ctrl+c' to exit ] Configuration file [/opt/apache/conf/httpd.conf]: /etc/httpd/conf/httpd.conf

step.para: The installer can change the directory ownership to the same User and Group specified in the Apache configuration. Enter yes to alter directory ownership, press Enter to accept the default: no.
step.screen: Change ownership of created directories using User and Group settings in httpd.conf [ q or 'ctrl+c' to exit ] (yes/no): [no]: yes

step.para: The installer can import settings from an existing web policy agent into the new installation and skips prompts for any values present in the existing configuration file. You will be required to re-enter the agent profile password.
Enter the full path to an existing agent configuration file to import the settings, or press Enter to skip the import.
step.screen: To set properties from an existing configuration enter path to file [ q or 'ctrl+c' to exit, return to ignore ] Existing agent.conf file:

step.para: Enter the full URL of the OpenAM instance the web policy agents will be using. Ensure that the deployment URI is specified.
step.screen: Enter the URL where the OpenAM server is running. Please include the deployment URI also as shown below: (http://openam.sample.com:58080/openam) [ q or 'ctrl+c' to exit ] OpenAM server URL: http://openam.example.com:8080/openam

step.para: Enter the full URL of the server the agent is running on.
step.screen: Enter the Agent URL as shown below: (http://agent.sample.com:1234) [ q or 'ctrl+c' to exit ] Agent URL: http://www.example.com:80

step.para: Enter the name given to the agent profile created in OpenAM.
step.screen: Enter the Agent profile name [ q or 'ctrl+c' to exit ] Agent Profile name: webagent4

step.para: Enter the OpenAM realm containing the agent profile.
step.screen: Enter the Agent realm/organization [ q or 'ctrl+c' to exit ] Agent realm/organization name: [/]: /

step.para: Enter the full path to the file containing the agent profile password created earlier.
step.screen: Enter the path to a file that contains the password to be used for identifying the Agent [ q or 'ctrl+c' to exit ] The path to the password file: /tmp/pwd.txt

step.para: The installer displays a summary of the configuration settings you specified.

If a setting is incorrect, type no, or press Enter. The installer loops through the configuration prompts again, using your provided settings as the default. Press Enter to accept each one, or enter a replacement setting.
If the settings are correct, type yes to proceed with installation.
step.screen:
Installation parameters:
OpenAM URL: http://openam.example.com:8080/openam Agent URL: http://www.example.com:80 Agent Profile name: webagent4 Agent realm/organization name: / Agent Profile password source: /tmp/pwd.txt
Confirm configuration (yes/no): [no]: yes Validating... Validating... Success. Cleaning up validation data... Creating configuration... Installation complete.

step.para: Upon successful completion, the installer adds the agent as a module to the Apache HTTP Server configuration file. You can find a backup configuration file in the Apache HTTP Server configuration directory, called http.conf_amagent_date_and_time_of_installation.

The installer also sets up configuration and log directories for the agent instance. Each agent instance that you install on the system has its own numbered configuration and logs directory. The first agent's configuration and logs are located under the directory web_agents/apache24_agent/Agent_001/.
The configuration files and log locations are as follows:

listitem.para: Contains the bootstrap properties the web policy agent requires to connect to OpenAM and download its configuration. Also contains properties that are only used if you configure the web policy agent to use local configuration.
Operational audit log directory, only used if remote logging to OpenAM is disabled.
Debug directory where the amAgent debug file resides. Useful in troubleshooting policy agent issues.

step.para: Start the Apache server in which you installed the web policy agent.

section.title: Installing Apache Web Policy Agents into a Virtual Host
section.para: Complete the following procedures to install Web Policy Agents ${agentsDocTargetVersion} into Apache HTTP Server virtual hosts.

Installing into an Apache virtual host is a manual process, which involves copying an instance directory created by the agentadmin installer and adding to the Apache configuration file of the virtual host.

tip.para: Check that you have completed the prerequisite steps before proceeding. See .

section.para: You will also need to have installed a web policy agent into the default root Apache configuration file before installing into a virtual host. See .

procedure.title: To Install the Web Policy Agent into Apache Virtual Hosts
procedure.para: This procedure assumes you have installed a web policy agent into the default root configuration of your Apache HTTP Server installation, with configuration in /web_agents/apache24_agent/instances/agent_1. To install into a virtual host, copy this configuration folder, modify required settings, and enable the web policy agent in the virtual host configuration file.

step.para: Shut down the Apache server where you plan to install the agent.
Locate the web policy agent configuration instance to duplicate, and make a copy, for example agent_2:
UNIX example:
step.screen: $ cd /web_agents/apache24_agent/instances $ cp -r agent_1 agent_2

step.para: Windows example:
step.screen: c:\> cd c:\web_agents\apache24_agent\instances c:\path\to\web_agents\apache24_agent\instances> xcopy /E /I agent_1 agent_2

step.para: Give the user that runs the virtual host modify privileges to the new instance folder. The following examples demonstrate giving privileges to the agent_2 configuration instance to a user named apache:
UNIX example:
step.screen: $ cd /web_agents/apache24_agent/instances $ chown -hR apache agent_2

step.para: Windows example:
step.screen: c:\> cd c:\web_agents\apache24_agent\instances c:\path\to\web_agents\apache24_agent\instances> icacls "agent_2" /grant apache:M

step.para: In the new instance folder, edit the /config/agent.conf configuration file as follows:
Alter the value of com.sun.identity.agents.config.username to be the name of the agent profile you created in OpenAM for the virtual host.
If you used a different password when creating the new agent profile in OpenAM, you will need to configure the encryption key and password value in the agent configuration file.
Generate a new signing key, by running agentadmin --k:

listitem.para: UNIX example:
Windows example:
listitem.screen: C:\> cd web_agents\apache24_agent\bin C:\web_agents\apache24_agent\bin> agentadmin --k Encryption key value: YWM0OThlMTQtMzMxOS05Nw==

step.para: Use the generated encryption key to encrypt the new password, by running agentadmin --p, specifying the encryption key and the new password:

listitem.para: UNIX example:
Windows example:

step.para: In the agent configuration file of the new instance, set the following properties:

listitem.para: com.sun.identity.agents.config.key to be the generated encryption key value.
For example:
com.sun.identity.agents.config.password to be the generated encrypted password value.
For example:

step.para: Replace any references to the original instance directory with the new instance directory. For example, replace the string agent_1 with agent_2 wherever it occurs in the configuration file.
Configuration options that are likely to require alterations include:

Replace any references to the original website being protected with the new website being protected. For example, replace http://www.example.com:80/amagent with http://customers.example.com:80/amagent.
Configuration options that are likely to require alterations include:
Save and close the configuration file.
Edit the Apache HTTP Server configuration file. This is the same file specified when installing the web policy agent into the default Apache website. For example, /etc/httpd/conf/httpd.conf.
At the end of the file the installer will have added three new lines of settings, for example:
step.screen: LoadModule amagent_module /web_agents/apache24_agent/lib/mod_openam.so AmAgent On AmAgentConf /web_agents/apache24_agent/bin/../instances/agent_1/config/agent.conf
step.para: Leave the first line, LoadModule ..., and move the other two lines into the virtual host configuration element of the default site, for example:
step.screen: <VirtualHost *:80> # This first-listed virtual host is also the default for *:80 ServerName www.example.com ServerAlias example.com DocumentRoot "/var/www/html" AmAgent On AmAgentConf /web_agents/apache24_agent/instances/agent_1/config/agent.conf </VirtualHost>

step.para: Copy the same two lines into the new virtual host, and replace agent_1 with the new agent configuration instance folder, for example agent_2:
step.screen: <VirtualHost *:80> ServerName customers.example.com DocumentRoot "/var/www/customers" AmAgent On AmAgentConf /web_agents/apache24_agent/instances/agent_2/config/agent.conf </VirtualHost>

tip.para: If the new virtual host configuration is in a separate file, copy the two configuration lines into the VirtualHost element within that file.

step.para: Save and close the Apache HTTP Server configuration file.
Start the Apache HTTP server in which you installed the web policy agent.

section.title: Installing Apache Web Policy Agents Silently
section.para: You can run a silent, non-interactive installation by running agentadmin --s, along with arguments used to configure the instance.

tip.para: Check that you have completed the prerequisite steps before proceeding. See .

section.para: The required arguments, and the order in which to specify them are:

listitem.para: Enter the full path to the Apache HTTP server configuration file. The installer modifies this file to include the web policy agent configuration and module.
Enter the full URL of the OpenAM instance the web policy agents will be using. Ensure the deployment URI is specified.
Enter the full URL of the server the agent is running on.
Enter the OpenAM realm containing the agent profile.
Enter the name given to the agent profile created in OpenAM.
Enter the full path to the file containing the agent profile password.
To have the installer change the ownership of created directories to be the same User and Group as specified in the Apache configuration, specify the optional --changeOwner switch.
Optionally have the installer proceed with a silent installation even if it cannot connect to the specified OpenAM server during installation, rather than exiting.

section.screen:
$ agentadmin --s \ "/etc/httpd/conf/httpd.conf" \ "http://openam.example.com:8080/openam" \ "http://www.example.com:80" \ "/" \ "webagent4" \ "/tmp/pwd.txt" \ --changeOwner \ --acceptLicence
OpenAM Web Agent for Apache Server installation.
Validating... Validating... Success. Cleaning up validation data... Creating configuration... Installation complete.

procedure.title: To remove Web Policy Agents from Apache HTTP Server

step.para: Shut down the Apache server where the agent is installed.
Run agentadmin --l to output a list of the installed web policy agent configuration instances.
step.screen:
$ ./agentadmin --l OpenAM Web Agent configuration instances:
id: agent_1 configuration: /opt/web_agents/apache24_agent/bin/../instances/agent_1 server/site: /etc/httpd/conf/httpd.conf
id: agent_2 configuration: /opt/web_agents/apache24_agent/bin/../instances/agent_2 server/site: /etc/httpd/conf/httpd.conf
id: agent_3 configuration: /opt/web_agents/apache24_agent/bin/../instances/agent_3 server/site: /etc/httpd/conf/httpd.conf
step.para: Make a note of the ID value of the configuration instance you want to remove.
Run agentadmin --r, and specify the ID of the web policy agent configuration instance to remove. A warning is displayed. Type yes to proceed with removing the configuration instance.
step.screen:
$ ./agentadmin --r agent_3
Warning! This procedure will remove all OpenAM Web Agent references from a Web server configuration. In case you are running OpenAM Web Agent in a multi-virtualhost mode, an uninstallation must be carried out manually.
Continue (yes/no): [no]: yes
Removing agent_3 configuration... Removing agent_3 configuration... Done.

step.para: Restart the Apache HTTP Server.
